div.head: REMARKS.
The Irishman in London.
div.p:
It is amusing to contemplate the various singularities of men.A physician once observed that he could tell of what country a man was, by his complaint. If it laid in the head, he was a Scotchman—if in the heart, he was an Irishman—if in the stomach, he was an Englishman The Cockney, to whom the V and the W are a source of as many perplexities as were the two Dromios to the good people of Ephesus, has his patent for cutting King George’s English most divertingly. The Welshman enjoys his leek, his pedigree, and his toasted cheese. The Irishman, his brogue and his bulls. There is no fun about a Scotchman ; unless (in the absence of a post) when he is excited to dance to his national fiddle: his peculiarities, though not pleasing, are nevertheless profitable—for, like the mouse in the fable, he generally becomes too proud and too pursy to creep in at the cranny from whence his leanness originally crept out. These characteristics have not escaped the observation of dramatic writers; and abundant mirth has been derived from their exhibition. The eccentricities of Pat A gentleman, stepping into the Belfast mail, was asked by an Irish waiter for something to drink, for the trouble of calling him. “To drink!” exclaimed the gentleman—“ why, I gave Rooney a shilling.” “Och! bat, plase your honour, I called him !” One Irishwoman, having fallen out with another, was complaining to to a third how sadly she had been abused by an Irishwoman. “And are you not an Irishwoman yourself?” exclaimed the latter. “Och! and to be sure I am; bat I don’t come from them hot parts that she does !” have not been behindhand in contributing their full share to the gayety of nations ; and, while we have laughed heartily at his careless humour, his queer-sounding compound epithets, his antipodean association of thunder and turf, and such-like comical amalgamations of elementary and vegetable matter, some kind-hearted trait, some dash of genuine feeling, has suddenly come across us, and made us long to take him by the hand and claim acquaintance,
even though we should receive the peculiar token with which St. Patrick is wont to greet his particular friends— “From his sprig of shilelah and shamrock so green !”

The farce of The Irishman in London is borrowed from “The Intriguing Footman, or the Humours of Harry Humbug,” a piece attributed to James Whiteley, formerly manager of the Nottingham and other provincial theatres, and acted at Sheffield in 1791. It was originally produced at Covent Garden, at Mr. Johnstone’s benefit; that admirable comedian taking the part of Murtoch Delany. It has little plot, but is very ingeniously made up of incident and character. It exhibits the various stratagems practised by Edward, an intriguing footman (the Harry Humbug of the original farce), to deliver a letter from his master, Captain Seymour, to Caroline, the daughter of one Mr. Frost, a pertinacious old gentleman, who had taken a voyage from the West Indies to London for the sole purpose of avoiding the importunities of the said captain, and of marrying the young lady to Mr. Colloony, a simple native of the Emerald Isle. The latter personage is accompanied, on his matrimonial trip, by his Irish servant, Murtoch Delany. This is enlivened by the introduction of Cubba, a faithful African, who falls in love with Murtoch, and in the simplicity of her heart acquaints him with his good fortune; and of Cymon, who is almost as full of quaint comparisons as Dean Swift’s celebrated song of Similes. There is nothing comical about Mr. Frost, but his passion for Louisa; the young lady’s return of his affection is, however, equally comical. The dialogue is pleasantly written ; and, what with Edward’s rattling rhodomontade, Cymon’s pat and provoking similes, and Murtoch Delany’s national whim, there is no want of amusement in this farce. One of its chief attractions was the original Planxty, which Johnstone sung in a manner that made every heart, Irish and English, dance to its melody.

A first-rate actor of Irish characters is indispensable on a London stage. We are not old enough to have seen Moody perform; but we remember him, many years ago, a hale, respectable-looking old gentleman, taking his walks in company with the veteran Boaden, the well- known performer of Robin Hood. Rock (with many declensions) was of the Moody school—rigidly true to the brogue, but occasionally heavy and listless. Webb
sings an Irish air with admirable spirit; but he cannot act. The late Mr. Connor acted with humour; but then (like the three unmusical rogues in good King Arthur's days)
«In good King Arthur’s days,
Oh, he was a very good king !
Three sons of w * * * * were turn’d out of doors
Because they couldn't sing !” he couldn't sing. Johnstone possessed both qualifications in high perfection: his voice was full, clear, and melodious—his acting rich, sparkling, and original. He was equally fine in genteel comedy and in the broadest farce——in the finished gentleman and the veriest Teague. His Major O'Flaherty was gallant and gay; his Foigard (Kilkenny, by my soul!) was arch and pointed. In Looney, he looked as if he had been born in a field, with a hay-fork in his hand. And how he stood up for the honour of ould Ireland and her “manufactrys,” and reiterated “bad travelling !” and “Oh! murther, murther !” those who have seen his Murtoch Delany can amply testify. His pathos was deep—his humour quick and sly; he had Pat’s hereditary fun and frisk—his national naiveté and dancing hilarity. He could assume a-look of brisk intelligence and of ineffable stupidity ; there was a peculiar archness in his smile, and he had an Irish front. To follow such an actor is no easy task; to fall short of him cannot be considered a failure. Mr. Power has many of the qualifications that distinguished his predecessor: his brogue is rich, his air smart and vivacious—the jokes come trippingly from his tongue, lighted up with a leer whimsically illustrative of potatoes and whiskey. His attempts have hitherto been confined to low comedy. His Irish Tutor is good—so are his Loony, Murtoch, and Dennis Bulgruddery. Mr. Power has a clear stage to himself; he has no competitor in Irish characters. To him we apply Walsh's advice to Pope,—“study correctness.” We have seen many a natural genius run to waste, for want of attending to this necessary precaution. However excellent nature is of herself, she may still derive improvement from art.

list.item: Frost.—Blue body coat, yellow waistcoat, nankeen trousers and gaiters, grey hair.
Colloony.—Cut-off green body coat, striped waistcoat, breeches, and striped boots.
Edward.—1st Dress: Undress livery. 2nd. Dress Eccentric suit. red Dress: Same as first.
Louisa and Caroline Modern young ladies dresses.
Cubba.— Striped dress, red ’kerchief round her head, black face and hands.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Welcome, once more, my native country! yet am I almost insensible to the pleasure, from being at so great a distance from my beloved Caroline.—Oh Jamaica, happy place! which contains all that is dear to me on earth. Her cruel father must have intercepted the letters I wrote from America, or she would have contrived to let her Seymour know, she still retained the same tender affection for him——Good heaven! is it possible? Ha! reason contradicts my sense of seeing, and tells my eyes they are deceived—'Tis he! Enter Mr. Frost, L. Dear sir, my joy at seeing the parent of my Caroline so unexpectedly——

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: (❌'s R.) This assurance is past bearing! I left the West Indies to live in quiet; and here, one of the first things that presents itself, is the person of all others I wish to avoid.—But my daughter is in my power, and shall marry the man I have selected for her directly—I'll take care of her happiness.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Great care, indeed, to sacrifice her against her inclinations to some wretch!—But who is he? Let me know where——

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: No matter who he is, or what he is; or where he lives, or where I live: you know but little of my family at present, and I am determined you shall know less. (Exit R.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Astonishing! 'Tis some comfort, however, to know she is in England,

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: (L)Oh, sir, such news! Miss Caroline is in town, has been here these two months—I found it out by the greatest chance.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: How, how?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Why, sir, I met Cymon, pretended to him that I had left you in America, and he told me they were all come; and that there was great doings preparing for an elegant young fellow from Ireland, who was to marry Miss Caroline immediately.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: By heavens! no such circumstance ever shall take place; and how to prevent it? Edward, you, in general, have a happy invention, and I am certain, if you exert it, you might gain me an interview, or, at all events, some further intelligence.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: (sings) "The perquisite softens us into consent."—Ah! my invention and genius are at present employed, contriving how I shall avoid the civilities of my tailor, shoemaker, washerwoman, and a few other friends, whom I left rather abruptly—Now they'll renew their former mode of paying their respects to me; and though I never return one visit, they'll still continue their kind enquiries. If I had but a few pounds to satisfy those gentry, my mind would be easy, my person free; and, thus disencumbered, I should most certainly devise means to deliver from my master a letter to his dear Caroline, before she consults her downy pillow this night.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: My honest fellow, make good your words, and twenty pounds shall be your reward.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Twenty pounds! twenty! She has—or I mean she shall have the letter. Write it, sir, write it—Let me have it.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: While I go to write, be very particular in observing any gentleman that may be hereabouts; and if he should seem at a loss, direct him to me, or come directly for me.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Oh sir, yonder I see my tailor—I told you these people would impede my march, if I was not prepared for them. Dear me, how shall I avoid him?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Avoid him. Who is he? What's his name?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p:
His name is a—the—oh damn it, 'tis very odd I never can remember the name of a man I owe money
to—that is, when I am poor; for then I am always dejected at the sight of them. But when I have money, and can pay them, I face them as bold as a lion. How do you do? says I, how do you do?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: With those principles, 'tis a pity you should ever want. Here, take this, and observe my directions while I write the letter. (Exit R.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: I will, sir.—What's here? ten poundss! Mr Snip!—Oh, he's off some other way, and I'll be hanged if I call him back—Let me see; ten pounds! My master is a noble fellow—I wish he was a General, then his pocket might keep pace with his heart. At present, the one is always a day's march behind the other. But how shall I contrive to deliver my master's letter? No matter I'll trust to chance, and convince him, with all his despair ——
sp.l: That English wit, howe'er despised by some,
Like English valour, still shall overcome.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Och ! London! London! dear London, as Ercher says, had I millions, I'd spend it all there ! it's the mert for enjoyment—the leedies so bewitching, the squeers so elegant, the theatres so enchanting, and, in short, every thing so captivating, that I wish, from my heart, I may never leave it. Where is this servant of mine? I decleer there is no bearing his inattention. I desired him to meet me here at this time precisely: 'pon my honour I must no longer neglect visiting Mr Frost and the leedies.

sp.speaker: Murtoch
sp.l: We Irishmen both high and low, we are both neat and handy,
The ladies every where we go, allows we are the dandy.
To be sure we are, and indeed we are -

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Indeed I'll break your thick head if you don't hold your tongue, and till me, did you find the pleece, and bring me the money?

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Well, well; I will sir—the—a—och, sir, I wish we were at home again; this is the divil of a place.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I say, sirrah, have you found the banker's?

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: No, in troth, sir.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: No! pray thin, where's the chick I gave you?

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Where! why sure, sir, you didn't bid me kape it.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I bid you give it to the banker, and bring me the money — where is it?

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Why, I'll tell you, sir—The truth is, I did not give him the chick—Nor the divil a farthing he gave me—for I didn't see him at all, at all.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Was there ever such a provoking scoundrel? Tell me this moment, where, and what you have been about ?

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Och! faith! and I have been tumbled about bravely; for the people here walk the streets as if they couldn't see—for one parson gave me a drive on one side, and when I only turned to ax him what he done that for, another gave me a shoulder with his elbow on the t'other side—So, upon my sowl, sir, I was going backward every step I went forward.—But at last, I saw a crowd staring up; so myself axed dacently what was the matter—Stop, and luck up, says the man, and you'll see: myself did so, and there was two black pictures of men, with shillelys in their fists, thumping at one another, because the clock was striking. When it had done, they had done, and I was done; for I found they picked my pocket of the chick that I held fast in my hand, and every thing I had in the world; and the hat off my head into the bargain!

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: The rascal has been gaping about, instead of minding his business.—I will most certainly send you home, Dill.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Och! worrow do, sir, send me home; but mind, I won't go by say, I got enough of that; if once I got to sweet Balinrobe, the devil burn me if ever I wish to see foreign parts again, or any but our netral parts at home—to be sure, it is the sweetest little place in the world, Ireland is.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Why, you scoundrel, do you want to bring a mob about us? hold your tongue about Ireland, I say—Go wait at home for me, and don't be exposing. (Exit R.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Exposing! to talk of Ireland! Faith, sir, begging your pardon, I think a man does not desarve to belong to any country, that's ashamed to own it.(Exit R.

div.head: SCENE SECOND.—A Chamber. Table and two chairs, doors R. 1 R. and L. 1 R.
div.stage: Enter Frost, Caroline, and Cubba, R.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Come, cheer up, Liny—Your lover certainly will be here to-day—The knot shall be tied to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p:
Dear sir, don't impose upon your Caroline the
misery of refusing, when nature powerfully informs her, 'tis her duty to obey you—Indeed, indeed, I never can love this Mr Colloony.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: How do you know? You have never seen him—Why, he is young, handsome, rich—

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Mention not his qualifications, sir, for my heart is engaged.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Yes, and my word is engaged—The young fellow coming all the way from Ireland on purpose—A fine settlement made on you—Is not that better than starving with your Seymour?

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: I don't know what your resolution may be, but mine is unalterably fixed—Dear sir, I have only to entreat you will give up the idea of plunging me in wretchedness—Remember that you're a father, sir, and that indulgence should ever unite with that name.(exit R.

sp.speaker: Cubba.
sp.p: Ah! poor missa, she be so good—Still she cry great deal—Bochro do wrong, laugh and be happy—nobody ought to be merry when missee frette.(exit R.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Ay, follow her, you—you—whenever I am vext, or in trouble, that angel of darkness is sure to come in my way—I tell her every hour that she is in a blessed land of liberty, that she's her own mistress, free as air, in hopes I shall get rid of her; but she won't stir—no, she sticks like birdlime. (a single knock, L.)Then, that cursed Cymon comes with his similes.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Well, sir, what do you want? Who was that knocked at the door?

sp.speaker: Cymon.
sp.p: A man, sir: he gave me this as nimble as a fencing-master, and stepped away like a dancing-master.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Oh curse your similes! Let me see, from Mr Colloony—That's delightful! [Reads.] "Sir, my anxiety to take you by the hand, can only be equalled by my passionate desire to see your amiable daughter, and with the speedy assistance of Hymen, shall glory in the liberty of being her slave. The earliest moment possible I hope to make acceptable to Mr Frost the devoirs of his truly devoted and most assured humble servant, William Patrick O'Brien Colloony." Oh! he's a fine ardent lover. They shall be married to-morrow morning—D'ye hear, Cymon? take care every thing is ready for the reception of your new master. How does my purchase come on, the coach horses?

sp.speaker: Cymon.
sp.p: Troth, sir, bad enough—They are only fit for the crows. One of them, the sorrel horse, puts me woundily in mind of a lawyer.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: A lawyer! How now, how can that be?

sp.speaker: Cymon.
sp.p: Why, sir, he is well paid for every journey he goes; and the other is downright game, for he'd sooner die than run. (exit L.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: That fellow's as bad to me as the gout—I can find no cure for him.

sp.speaker: Cymon.
sp.p: Sir, sir—here's a grand gentleman dressed like a peacock, and talks like a magpie.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Was there ever such an affronting scoundrel! show him in. (exit Cymon, L.) It must be Mr Colloony—I say, Cubba, send your mistress to me immediately—Oh dear, this is lucky.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Did you send for me, sir?

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Yes, yes; here's Mr Colloony—it can be nobody else. Enter Edward, L. dressed in a tawdry manner. Sir, I rejoice to see you—how do you? so is my daughter, indeed, sir, though she says nothing— (to her) Why the devil don't you speak?

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Sir, I—I—

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: (aside) I have got into the house at all events, and must trust to impudence for the rest !

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Sir, she's excessively fond of you; but she naturally expects you to speak first.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Certainly, my dear sir—Fond of me! Oh, ho! then I must be in love—Here goes! (aside) Oh, Madam, you're such a beauty, so full of charms, so all over engaging, such a hand, such symmetry, such eyes, such lips, such smiles, such frowns, such love, such——Oh! I'm quite out of breath.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Well, this is a comical fellow! How he has gallopped over the poor girl! I don't think he has much of the brogue—But, sir, I say, my—

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p:
Then, her foot, sir—do but look at her foot, sir—A foot proportioned to the body; the body suited to the face, the face suited to the soul, the soul to the heart, the heart to the mind, the mind to—as my friend Hamlet says, in his advice to the actors, "the action to the word;" and then she has so much—Oh dear, oh dear, I can go
no further—Now to try to give her the letter. (aside, ❌'s L.)]

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: How his tongue does run! I am afraid Liny will never have him, he's such a fool. But, sir, you confound her with your compliments.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Compliments - you wrong me, sir; I can't flatter—I truly love, I adore, I live for you—I—I can't find the letter (aside, ❌'s C.)]—Oh, madam! say that you'll marry me, or I shall curse my stars, go mad, and die!

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Die ! you're the strangest fish I ever met with. Sir, I'll speak to my daughter, and if—

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Oh! that if has driven me to despair, for— (aside) I have lost the letter—My peace of mind is— Hang me, but it's gone! (aside)] It has undone my quiet, ruined me, blasted all my hopes—Farewell, board-wages, laced liveries, all joy, peace, happiness! Oh!, farewell!

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Sir, I'll withdraw a little to order some refreshment, and— (❌'s R.)

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Dear sir, don't leave me with this wretch, this fool!

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Don't abuse him, Liny; 'tis your charms have made him a little flighty—I wish they had cut his wings before they had let him away, for he's the wildest Irishman I ever saw. (exit R.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Sir, I say—

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Stop, madam, for heaven's sake!—I am Edward—my master, Captain Seymour, is in town.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Ha! can it be! My Seymour in England!

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am, and has sent you— (searching for letter.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: I don't like leaving my child with this wild Irishman. Eh! egad they seem very quiet, I'll listen.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Dear, dear, I have certainly left it in my other clothes—But the circumstance is this, ma'am— my master, this morning, saw your father; and, on finding you were in town, wrote a letter, which I undertook to deliver to you. (Frost comes between them - Caroline sees him and runs off R. Edward continues telling her of the letter.) But I have unfortunately mislaid it—I can assure you he loves you as much as ever; and if you would but write a few lines, to say that you love him, he'll run away with you, in spite of that cruel curmudgeon your father, and (turning about, meets Mr. Frost face to face.) Oh! murder!

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Thieves! Cymon! thieves! knock him down!

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Yes, sir.—(knocks Cymon down as he enters L., and exits L.).

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Oh! Murder! thieves!—Cymon, where are you?

sp.speaker: Cymon.
sp.p: Here I be, sir, as flat as a flounder.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: My poor fellow!—Go shut the door, and be sure to bolt, lock, and chain it.

sp.speaker: Cymon.
sp.p: Yes, sir—I'll see every thing as safe as a guinea in a miser's purse.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Oh! curse your similes!—I must go myself, and see every thing secure.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Thank heaven! I know my Seymour is in England—I have heard enough to convince me he still loves me; and constancy's the only proof of true affection—I hope he may devise some means to free me.

sp.speaker: Louisa.
sp.p: If he did not, I am sure he should not have me.

sp.speaker: Cymon.
sp.p: Ma'am, he's come; Mr Colloony. Oh dear! I am as much out of breath as a trumpeter.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: (without, L. Walk in—walk in, sir.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: I am overjoyed to see you, walk in, sir, walk in. Ladies, ladies, this is Mr Colloony: Sir, my daughter and her friend Miss Belmont.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Ladies, your most obedient. This warm and kind reception is truly flattering, and impresses me strongly with the idea of my future happiness.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Oh! I'm sure you'll be very happy——There's a husband for you, Liny! Is he to be compared to your captain?

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: No, indeed, sir, I don't think he is.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: That's a good girl—Well, sir—You shall be married this morning—Oh dear! and how is my old friend, your worthy father, and all your family? What sort of a passage had you? I suppose you were very much fatigued after your journey? Will you have some refreshment? Oh! I'm so happy! Come tell me all.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p:
All, upon my honour, he asks all, and will hear
nothing—Sir, I left my father and all the family very well, as his letters will acquaint you—I say, Dill, bring up that parcel, Dill, I say, Dill.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Here, sir, here! Arrah, Maister Pat, don't be calling me Dill, myself can't bear it; it's making so little of one. My name, ladies, saving your prisence, is Murtoch Delany; and though Maister Pat's my maister, I don't know who made him my godmother.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Get away, sirrah, Sir, you will find by these letter the liberality of my father, he gives me his whole estate while he lives; and makes me heir to all the rest when he dies.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Oh, the divil burn the blade of grass, horse, cow, servant, or any other fixture upon the estate, even to the value of a sucking-pig, but will be all his own.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Oh! I'm too happy. You shall be united directly.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I should think myself unworthy, indeed, if words could express how much I feel indebted to your goodness. Before I had the felicity of seeing the lady I could think of nothing else; and such an effect had the description of her on my mind, I decleer I could not sleep a wink for draming of her.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: But you did not tell me what sort of a passage you had.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Why, sir, they said it was a good one, but I was sick of it.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Sick! Arrah, ladies, we were kilt, myself was quite dead, I was all—a—I called to the captain to stop; "stop and put me out", says I. "Nonsince, man," says he, "if I put you out, it will be in the water, and then you'll go to Davy Jones.@ "Oh, thank you," says I, "it's time enough for me to go and live with that jintleman when I am dead in earnest.

sp.speaker: Louisa.
sp.p: Then you are not fond of the sea, Mr Colloony?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: No, indeed, ma'am; if they'd give me the finest estate upon earth, I could not live in it with any enjoyment on board of ship.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: But come, are not the towns through which you came worthy of observation?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Certainly, sir; your manufactories are so astonishingly greet, they prove at once the wonderful industry and wealth of your nation.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Ax your pardon, ladies, the devil a manufactory I saw equal to our own. Och! if you could only look at the oyster-beds in Poolbeg, the Foundling or the Lying-in-Hospital at Dublin, they are the right sort of manufactories.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Faith you may laugh, but I am sure there can't be better manufactries in the world than those that provides comfortable lodgings, and every other sort of bread and meat, for poor craters that can't provide for themselves.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Hold your preeting, sirrah; leedies, I hope you'll excuse him.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: But, Mr Colloony, do now favour us with your opinion of our country, and an account of your journey.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: 'Twas a very pleasant journey. Travelling here is much better than in Ireland.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Oh! murther, murther! Maister Pat, don't be running down our country; myself can't bear it; you know the roads are a thousand times better in Ireland. Ladies, the miles there are three times as long as they are here; and then the divil a half mile can you go, but there's a beautiful wooden milestone; I'm sure from the time we left the hill of Howth, till we got to that spalpeen place they call Holy-head, the divil a bit of land I saw but what was all covered over with water. Pretty travelling indeed!

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Begone, you scoundrel - lave the room, I say.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Lave the room, I say, sir.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Lave the room, you say, sir? Oh, mighty well; there's more o' the yarn. Did you think I was going to take it wid me? Bad travelling in Ireland! I'll say nothing before the company, but if ever I forgive this ! Ladies, your most engaging conversation— (goes muttering)] I never can forgive this. (exit L.)

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Your father, in this letter, seems particularly anxious that the marriage ceremony should be performed as soon as possible; now I'm desirous it should be so too; what do you say, sir?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: What do I say, sir? why I say, ask the lady; I deem it the happiest moment of my life! He must be covetous indeed, that could form a wish beyond what is here to be found. (bows to Louisa)

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p:
Liny, thank him—Isn't he an elegant, polite,
well-bred man? An't you surprised and rejoiced?—The licence is ready—I'll go to the parson; it must be done before twelve; we have but an hour and a half.

sp.speaker: Louisa.
sp.p: Caroline, how could you treat Mr Colloony in such a manner? you scarce looked at him. Are not you on the very brink of matrimony? To disappoint him now, what would the world say?

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Yet disappointed he shall be, and I am in no dread of what people may say—The truly virtuous mind makes itself judge, and, satisfied within, smiles at that common enemy, the world.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Come, girls, prepare; Louisa, you shall go too—you shall be a bridesmaid. Hadn't you rather be a bride?

sp.speaker: Louisa.
sp.p: Why, sir, I can't say I should have any objection.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Oh, charming! you make me young again—Egad, I begin to think—Oh dear—go and prepare, for Mr Colloony will return directly. (exit Louisa, R.) Oh, the lovely, sweet——

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Well, sir, what do you want?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Sir, I—a—beg pardon, sir, I believe I am come to the wrong house——

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Then pray, sir, go to the right house.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Yes, sir. (exit, singing, L.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Do, sir. Cymon, who is that fellow? He had but an ill look, methought. Shut the door there. Now, Liny my love, be a good girl. I'm so pleased, that I shall give you an additional hundred pounds, for you to—— Enter Edward, L. He here again! I thought you were gone to the right house!

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: This is it, sir. Pray did not a gentleman of the name of Colloony—I got that from the Irish servant (aside)]—go out of this house a little time ago?

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Yes, sir; but if you want him, he'll be back directly.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: No, sir, he will not, a sad accident has happened to him.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Mercy on me! I hope not.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Truth indeed, sir—I'll tell you the particulars. At the corner of the next street a gentleman attacked him. "Sir", says he, "you are a villain!", then drew his sword, and pushed violently at him. Thus, sir, thus, madam—thus (pushes the letter over Frost's shoulder, which she does not notice.) Oh, the blind creature!

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Dear me, how unlucky! I wish he was returned, I hope he is not hurt.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: He is, sir; yes, he is—It's rather an odd place.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Where? where? Is it in a mortal part?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: It's in the back, sir—in the back, ma'am, in the back—Damme but she'll die a maid. (he turns his back to her, and the letter is fastened to it; she takes no notice of it)] And so Captain Seymour, ma'am——

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Oh! that cursed captain!

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Captain! What was it my——?

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: No, no, it was not.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Yes, yes, ma'am, it was—a——

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Stopping his mouth. No, no, she must not know he is so near her. I don't think, at least, I hope it was not Mr Colloony.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Yes, it was, sir.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Why, how was the gentleman dressed?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Why, sir, he was dressed in a pair of boots, sir, and a hat, sir, with a band round the hat, sir. fixes the letter in his hat-band and pushes it towards her - she takes it.)

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: And how is Mr Colloony? Tell me.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Why, sir, as soon as Captain Seymour saw the blood trickle from his antagonist, he jumped to him, took him in his arms, thus, and carried him to Dr Julep's this way.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Blessed contrivance! 'tis from my Henry; but how to send an answer? If I go to my room, Edward may be gone before I can write—What shall I do? Invention assist me. (writes with her pencil on the Letter)]

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: But what did the doctor think him in danger?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Why, sir, we hope not—He probed the wound, and after muttering a great many gallipot phrases, that none but the brethren of the pill-boxes understand, he pronounced him out of danger, and ordered him to be put to bed, his stomach to be fomented with a—a—bason of soup, and—

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: If this does but succeed—(aside). Sir, sir, this fellow's an impostor—I'll let my honoured father know your villainy—Sir, while you were listening to his story, he forced this letter into my hand; but to show how I regard the writer, there, take his impertinent scrawl back again. throws it on the ground.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: The art of man won't prevent her being an old maid.—Ma'am——

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Oh, you damn'd dog! Let me see it, my dear—We'll throw it into the fire, and this fellow out of the window.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: No, sir, I cannot wish him a greater punishment than to return his letter just in that manner.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Here's usage for my poor master—but, Ma'am, is there nothing for—or by way of—a—

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Oh, you want something, do you? I'll pay you (beats Edward off, L. —there's wood upon wood. Come along, Liny, and if ever I catch you in this house again, I'll leave you no more brains than a fiddler. (exeunt nFrost and Caroline, R.

div.l: Och, whiskey, it's you that's my darling,
It's you that keeps me on my feet,
And often you cause me to stagger,
Wheniver we chance for to mate.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Maister Pat, I'm come to desire that you will—a—Oh, he's gone! It's well for him—I was just going to discharge him—he vexes me so when he speaks congrumshously about the sod—I won't, for I can't bear it—I have made Cymon blind drunk in love wid Ireland—I was telling him all about it, and he supped up my intelligence like a jintleman; to be sure he mixt it a little, for he emptied the best part of two bottles of port, that Miss gave him to make much of me, and there he lies stretched on the floor, snoring as quiet as a stone in a wall. I'm quite up—I'm almost corned, faith, with looking at him drinking it. I wish I had something to do—that somebody would affront me, or a fine young lady fall in love with me—or any divarting accident of that nater.

sp.speaker: Cubba.
sp.p: You want to speak a wi' me.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p:
Och, honey, what's this? Sure the crater
wou'dn't be in love with me—She is, she is! And I am sorry for her—but she can't help it—Honey, it won't do—Now don't think of it, avourneen.

sp.speaker: Cubba.
sp.p: Me no understand you.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: She does not understand me—What a misfortune it is to want larning—if your schoolmistress had been a jintleman, she'd tache you the manners to say you did, whether or not. I'll larn you to spake good English when my master marries your young lady.

sp.speaker: Cubba.
sp.p: Me hope me not live till den, me sure missee break her heart, and me rader die den see it.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Oh faith, if you die, you won't see it to be sure—May be you'll hear of it, and that will be the same thing—Miss a—troth I forget your name.

sp.speaker: Cubba.
sp.p: Me name Cubba.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Pooh, pooh, be asy, Miss Cubbaugh!—That's being too agreeable— and your father's a king!

sp.speaker: Cubba.
sp.p: Iss, a king.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Oh! it's king of the morice-dancers she manes; ay, ay, that fellow had a black face—I saw him yesterday.

sp.speaker: Cubba.
sp.p: No, no; him live at de Gold Coast.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Where? Where all the silver comes from, eh?

sp.speaker: Cubba.
sp.p: At de Gold-Coast—Now nobody here, you shut your eye, me tell you something dat make my heart open in two. But you look so good—you not be angry with Cubba.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Oh! the divil an angry I'll be—I never was angry with one of the fair sex in my life—There, honey, my eyes are shut—go on—now the divil a word I can hear.

sp.speaker: Cubba.
sp.p: Me love a you dearly—but me no want you love me—dat be very wrong—Your face white, me poor negro—me only tell you make me easy, den me pray for you be happy.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: I knew it—I knew it—Black, brown, green, or yellow, I bother them all—Oh, Murtoch, you murtherer of beauty—What are you about—but the milk of compassion rises within me for poor Cubbaugh—I wish she was not sooty. Who knows, may be the journey will bleach her. Troth, it's a shame your mistress never found out that fellow, that advertises to whiten ladies' hands and faces, he'd make you fair as a daisy. Och! if you had even a bit of the violent soap, honey!

sp.speaker: Cubba.
sp.p: No matter, my color, if me do right—Good black face be happier den bad white. (Exit Cubba, R.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p:
Troth and I believe she may be the daughter of
a king, for she has the mind of a prince—If her face was but as white as her heart, she'd be a wife for a Pope. I'll take her wid me to ould Ireland, and sing her every night the praise of the most beautiful flower of the earth,. and the finest gim of the say.

div.l: If you'd travel the wide world all over,
And sail across quite round the globe,
You must set out on horseback from Dover,
And sail unto sweet Balinrobe.
'Tis there you'll see Ireland so famous,
That was built before Adam was breech'd,
Who lived in the reign of King Shamus,
Ere he was at Boyne over-reach'd.
With my whack fal de ral, &c.
O, the Land of Shillelah for me.
There you'll see Ulster, and Munster, and Leinster,
Connaught, and sweet Kilkenny likewise,
That city where first, as a spinster,
I open'd these pair of black eyes;
In this town there is fire without smoking,
For a penny you'd buy fifty eggs,
And then there's such wit without joking,
And rabbits without any legs.
With my whack, &c.
There you'll see my ancestors glorious,
The sons of the brave O's and Mac's,
Who died whene'er they were victorious,
And after that ne'er turn'd their backs.
Our heads are stout and full of valour,
Our hearts are wise and full of brains,
In love we ne'er blush nor change colour,
And the ladies reward all our pains.
With my whack, &c.
Saint Patrick is still our protector,
He made us an island of saints, Drove out snakes and toads like an Hector,
And ne'er shut his eyes to complaints.
Then if you would live and be frisky,
And never die when you're in bed,
Come to Ireland and tipple the whiskey,
And drink tin years after you're dead.
With my whack fal de ral, &c.
The Land of Shillelah for me!

div.head: SCENE THIRD.—A Street.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: There's your letter again; that's all the answer I could get.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: My letter! 'Sdeath, you rascal, is this your boasted cleverness? Did you see my Caroline?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Yes, sir; and after many efforts, at last I gave the letter into her own hand, and her father in the room. But she returned it just as you see, and is positively to be married this morning.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Unlucky scoundrel! 'tis to you I owe all my misfortunes; by listening to your wretched paltry schemes, I have lost all that was dear to me on earth; but you shall injure me no more—all the punishment I can at present inflict is, to divest you of my property, and discard you—so strip, sir, and never let me see your face again.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Call a coach, sir, throw the clothes into it, and begone—Strip, I say.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: What, sir, in the street? I shall catch cold, sir.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Do as I desire you, rascal, or——

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Yes, sir, yes—coach—co—Lord, sir, you are joking!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: I am serious, sirrah—Do as I order you;—no words—but—

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Yes, sir, yes—Here's gratitude! who the devil would be a footman now, I wonder.—There, sir, there's your coat, all the rest is my own.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Quit my sight—and here, sir, take this letter as your reward.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Oh! sir, virtue is its own reward—I look for none. Eh! what's this? (sees the writing on letter) Ha! kind fortune, you never deserted me.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: What is the fellow loitering about? I wish he'd ask for his coat again. (aside.)]

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Sir, I have one favour to beg before I go; will you be so kind, as just to look at the outside of that letter?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p:
Look at —— (taking letter)] Ha! what's here? (reads) "This is the only method I have to acquaint my dear Seymour
, that I am still the same; my heart is wholly his." Transport! (kisses the letter)] Charming!

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Ahem! ahem!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: My dear Edward, what shall I say to you?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Nothing, sir; you've said enough—'Tis to me you owe all your misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Nay, nay, put on your coat.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: No, no, sir; get another servant. I'll never——

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Nay, for Heaven's sake, Edward—I own I have been rash.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Rash! to make me strip here in the open street, and expose me to all the world——(walking about from L. to R.)

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: But, Edward, do put on your coat.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Not I, sir, I despise a coat—when there's no money in the pockets.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Now, my dear fellow, have done.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Lord, sir, I have done; money and a good place have stopped greater men's mouths than mine.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Take your coat, and put it on.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Yes, sir—A little of your assistance, if you please.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: My assistance!

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Yes, sir, I'll not put it on without it. (Seymour helps him on with his coat. I have often assisted you on a similar occasion.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Well, come, only think of my anxiety.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Who would not be a footman now? It's well you're a gentleman, sir.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: You make a very good master, but you'd be a precious bad servant.

sp.speaker: Cubba.
sp.p: Massa, bring a my dear good Missee to make her marry great man. She send a me to look for you. Here a shee come. Oh, dear, Missa!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Why, there's no man but her father.

sp.speaker: Cubba.
sp.p: Na; chum-chum meet her at the church.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Never! let the consequence——

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Here they come, sir. Let's retire a little—Come, Cubba, and mind what I say. (they retire)

div.stage: Enter Frost and Ladies, one on each side, L.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p:
Dear me, the time is getting rapidly over, and I
dread that fellow's having any more schemes to bamboozle and cheat me; but I think if he does now, he must be cunning. Come on, Liny.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Why, sir, how very ridiculous you'll make yourself and me in this business—You see, plainly, Mr Colloony won't be here. Pray, sir, put it off till to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: No, no; I am certain he will be here—Egad, yonder he comes—Louisa, your turn shall be next—tomorrow, we'll—oh dear!

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I hope, sir, I have'n't kept you weeting. Madam, I take addresses himself to Louisa. Edward takes Cubba's hand, slips Caroline's gently away, and puts Cubba's in its place, under Frost's arm, Seymour and Carolione run off R.U.E, followed bt Edward.)

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Mr Colloony, don't be ashamed to be seen with your wife before marriage—here she—Oh the devil!

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Arrah, is it my own little daffy-down-dilly you want, Maister Pat, to bring home? Oh thunder! arrah! be asy!

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Oh! thunder indeed! What hocus pocus is this?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Sir, I take your daughter as the greetest gift this world can be—

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Take her! where will you find her?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Here, sir—This lady—

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: That lady! No, no, no; she is no daughter of mine—She is engaged—She is—Oh, Liny! Why don't you pursue and bring back your wife that is to be? This poor girl has no fortune.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Why then it is very lucky I have enough for us both; and if this lady will make it more by sharing it with me, it's all at her service.

div.stage: Enter Seymour, Caroline, and Edward, R.U.E.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Dear sir, be reconciled; and our future conduct shall prove, that to make you happy is all we wish.

sp.speaker: Frost.
sp.p: Ah, confound you all! I'll never—yet stop; she is yours, sir, with a good fortune, and the blessing of an affectionate father.

sp.speaker: Murt.
sp.p: Faith, you're right, old gentleman—But all our great joy and happiness, will be nothing but downright grief and misery, if the hands of all our friends do not loudly whisper in our ears, they have no objection to the "IRISHMAN IN LONDON."

div.stage: R. Edw. Car. Sey. Frost. Coll. Lou. Murt. Cubba. L.
